transcript.text: Hello everyone, welcome to Nesoo Academy. We have already completed chapter number 4, control structures and functions. Now we are in chapter number 5 and the name of this chapter is Object Oriented Programming. From this chapter onwards, we will dive deeper into the concepts of Object Oriented Programming and the focus of this chapter is to understand the basics of Object Oriented Programming or in short, OOP. This is the first lecture of this chapter and the name of this lecture is Procedural vs Object Oriented Programming. In this lecture, we will properly understand the difference between Procedural Programming and Object Oriented Programming. So, let's get started with this lecture and let's see what are the topics. There is only one topic in this lecture and the name of the topic is Procedural vs Object Oriented Programming. So, we will properly understand the difference between the two, let's dive in and let's understand the difference. We have Procedural Programming at Object Oriented Programming. To understand the difference between the two, first we need to recall what is Procedural Programming. Up to now, whatever programs we have built were built using Procedural Programming. This means we have developed the programs that are all Procedural programs. In Procedural Programming, the focus is on creating procedures or in other words, functions. We know what a function is. A function is something that has the capability to perform some task. If we have multiple functions, then we would be able to perform multiple tasks. When these functions are combined together, then we would be able to solve a big problem. And that is exactly what Procedural Programming is. In Procedural Programming, the focus is in creating procedures or in other words, functions. Through functions, we solve big problems. In Procedural Programming, we need to understand this that the data and functions are separate entities and programmer has to combine them to produce the desired result. Data and functions are separate entities in Procedural Programming. It is not the case that data is tied to the functions. It is the responsibility of the programmer to combine data and functions to produce the desired result. This can be understood through an example as well. Here, I am calling some function called push. And to this function, I am passing the arguments man and door. Let us assume there is some function called push. And to the push function, we are passing two arguments, man and door. Here, the data has to be passed explicitly. While defining the functions, we need to define the parameters explicitly. Here, the data and function are not combined together automatically. They are separate entities and it is the responsibility of the programmer to combine them to produce the desired result. When we pass data to the function, then only the function would be able to perform some operations on it and will eventually give us some output. So, that is the case with Procedural Programming. Also, we can see that it is quite unclear whether man is the subject or door is the subject. So, it is unclear who is the subject and who is the object. Or in other words, we can say that it is unclear to us whether man is pushing the door or door is pushing the man. So, understandability is quite less in procedural programming because procedural programming is quite unnatural way of programming. It does not mimic the real world entities properly. In real world, everything is an object with some properties and behavior. By properties, I mean data and by behavior, I mean functions. Every object that we consider around us has some properties and behavior. Let's take one example. Let's take the example of a car. Car has properties like color, mileage, speed or we can say maximum speed. Apart from this, car also has some behaviors. It has the behavior to stop, to start or to move. These are different behaviors of the car. So, clearly an object has properties and behavior tied to that. So, we can say data and functions are inseparable. That is what I have written here. Data and functions are inseparable. They both are tied together within an object. That is what we can see in the real world. Now, this modeling cannot be done with the help of procedural programming because the focus is on creating procedures or functions and data and functions are separate entities in procedural programming. And with procedural programming, we would not be able to achieve scalability. That is, we cannot design big programs without making a lot of changes. If we want to add new features to the program, then we need to make a lot of changes in the program. So, this is procedural programming. Now, this is not the only model of programming that we have. We also have object-oriented programming. Let's understand what is object-oriented programming. In object-oriented programming, the focus is on creating user-defined data types containing both properties and behavior. So, what happens in case of object-oriented programming? The focus is in creating user-defined data types. So, there is a shift in the focus. In procedural programming, we were focusing on functions or procedures. But here, the focus is on creating user-defined data types that contains both properties and behavior. So, properties and behavior are combined together within a user-defined data type. This is what happens in case of object-oriented programming. And an object is an instance of the user-defined type. By user-defined type, I mean a class. We call that user-defined type in object-oriented programming a class. And object is just an instance of the class. We can understand this through an example. What is the meaning of instance? Let's say we have the class vehicle. Vehicle has many properties and behavior. And these properties and behavior are common to all the vehicles that we see now. We have car, bike, truck. These are different types of vehicles. We can call these types as objects. They are the instances or we can say occurrences of the class. They all have the properties and behavior of the class vehicle. But they are different in their own way. They have their own properties as well. They have their own behavior. But car, bike and truck are all the objects of the class vehicle. So we can say an object is an instance of the user-defined type. Or we can say an example of the user-defined type. I hope this is clear to you. Now let's take the same example of the push function. But in a different way in object-oriented programming. This is how the push function looks like. And this is how we can call this function. We need to call this function through an object. And that too with the help of the dot operator. And here you can observe it is completely clear that man is pushing the door. We read from left to right and we can observe that man is pushing the door. So it is clear that man is the subject, pushes the behavior and door is the object. So one thing is clear that with object-oriented programming we can design objects with properties and behavior in built. And therefore we can model real world entities quite properly. Hence this is more natural way of programming compared to procedural programming. In object-oriented programming we would be able to model real world entities properly. That allows us to solve problems more naturally and efficiently. By efficiency I mean that we would be able to design our programs with more scalability. You will observe this in a moment why object-oriented programming is good for scalability. We would be able to add more features in the program without the need of modifying the program a lot. This is not the case with procedural programming. So object-oriented programming is more suitable in those situations when we want to design big programs and when we want our applications to be more scalable. I hope this idea is completely clear to you. So through object-oriented programming we can model real world entities as you can observe and modeling real world entities is more natural as well and it is more understandable. So now we know in theoretical terms what is the difference between procedural programming and object-oriented programming. Now let's understand why object-oriented programming is better in comparison to procedural programming especially when scalability comes into picture.
